mdRecord.dcterms:description: As part of Jefferson's design for UVA's Academical Village, professors lived and taught in unique Pavilions, which each served as a distinct model of architectural ideals. Pavilion Two features a three bay facade with monumental columns. Jefferson's notes indicate that Pavilion Two's portico and entablature are inspired by Palladio's depiction of the Ionic of Fortuna Virilis in Rome. The original marble capitals, still in place, were carved in Carrara, Italy. Pavilion Two's first long-term resident was Anatomy and Surgery Professor Thomas Johnson. [work]
